titleStmt.title: The effect of glass composition on the thermodynamics of the Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ equilibrium and the iron diffusivity in Na 2 O/MgO/CaO/Al 2 O 3 /SiO 2 melts

analytic.title: The effect of glass composition on the thermodynamics of the Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ equilibrium and the iron diffusivity in Na 2 O/MgO/CaO/Al 2 O 3 /SiO 2 melts

div.p: Melts in the system Na 2 O/MgO/CaO/Al 2 O 3 /SiO 2 doped with 0.25 mol% Fe 2 O 3 were studied using square-wave voltammetry at temperatures in the range from 1000 to 1600 8C. The voltammograms exhibited a distinct peak attributed to the Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ -redox reaction. The peak potential is equal to the standard potential of the redox pair and from the peak current, the iron diffusion coefficients can be calculated. With increasing temperature, the peak is shifted to less negative potentials, due to the shift of the redox equilibrium to the reduced state, Fe 2+ . Increasing Na 2 O concentrations in melts without alumina lead to a shift in the peak potential to more negative potentials and to smaller viscosity corrected iron diffusion coefficients. This can be explained by the stabilization of FeO 4 À tetrahedra by Na + ions. Introducing alumina leads to less negative peak potentials and increasing viscosity corrected diffusion coefficients. In analogy to Fe 3+ , alumina is incorporated as AlO 4

À tetrahedra which need alkali for charge compensation. If the molar alumina concentration exceeds that of Na 2 O, additional alumina is no longer charged balanced, the peak potentials get more negative and the viscosity corrected iron diffusion coefficients decrease again. If CaO is introduced into the melt, the maxima in the peak potentials (as a function of the Al 2 O 3 concentration) and viscosity corrected iron diffusion coefficients do no longer occur at [
. This is evidence that the charge of AlO 4

À tetrahedra can also be compensated by Ca 2+ ; however, one Ca 2+ can stabilize only one AlO 4 À tetrahedron and not two. In magnesia containing melts, the maxima in the peak potentials and iron diffusion coefficients occur at

Hence, Mg 2+ does not contribute to the stabilization of AlO 4 À and FeO 4 À tetrahedra; however, increasing MgO concentrations lead to more negative peak potentials. This can be explained by the similarities of the ionic radii and metal-oxygen bond lengths of Mg 2+ and Fe 2+ . Increasing MgO concentrations hence lead to the incorporation of Fe 2+ in energetically less advantageous sites which favours the Fe 3+ redox state. Empirical equations are given which allow to calculate standard potentials, equilibrium constants and hence Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ redox ratios from the chemical composition.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: At high temperatures, Fe 2+ , Fe 3+ and the physically dissolved oxygen of a melt form an equilibrium.
The attributed equilibrium constant K depends on temperature as well as on the melt composition.
div.formula: K T ð Þ ¼ a 4 Fe 2þ a O 2 a 4 Fe 3þ a 2 O 2Àð2Þ
div.p: with: a i =activities of the respective species in the melt. In the case of iron, the equilibrium according to Eq. ( 1) is shifted to the right with increasing temperature. Since the activity of O 2À is unknown and K(T) does not decrease with the melt basicity, it is more suitable to describe the redox equilibrium by an equilibrium constant KV(T) defined as follows.
div.formula: KV T ð Þ ¼ K T ð Þa 2 O 2À ¼ a 4 Fe 2þ a O 2 a 4 Fe 3þð3Þ
div.p: Since the concentration of the physically dissolved oxygen in silicate melts of geological importance is usually much smaller than the iron concentration (as reported by Ru ¨ssel et al., 1988), the equilibrium according to Eq. (1) will not be shifted noticeable during quenching, if no other polyvalent ion, such as manganese or arsenic occurs in the melt. Therefore, equilibrium constants can be determined by equilibrating a melt with an atmosphere of well-defined oxygen fugacity, quenching the sample and analyzing the Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ -ratio physically or chemically. In highly viscous silicate melts, this is a time consuming process, because diffusion of oxygen in or out of the melt is necessary and the enhancement by convection is less pronounced. It has always to be ensured that the melt is really in equilibrium with the atmosphere or, however, the oxygen activity of the melt has to be measured (using ZrO 2 -based sensor, as described by Schaeffer et al., 1982). In the literature, numerous studies on Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ -redox equilibria have been reported using equilibration methods (see Maric et al., 1989;Paul, 1985, Paul and Douglas, 1965, Schreiber, 1986;Schreiber and Balazs, 1981). In the past decades, redox equilibria have frequently been studied using electrochemical methods (see e.g. Johnston, 1964or Takahashi and Miura, 1980, 1987) especially the square-wave-voltammetry (see Claugen andRu ¨ssel, 1996, 1998;Gerlach et al., 1998cGerlach et al., , 1999;;Wiedenroth and Ru ¨ssel, 2001, 2002b, 2003a,b;Ru ¨ssel, 1993). These methods are carried out directly at melt temperatures using electrodes inserted into the melts. Besides data on the redox equilibrium also diffusion coefficients are obtained from the voltammograms recorded, as reported e.g. by Gerlach et al. (1998a,b) and Wiedenroth andRu ¨ssel (2002a, 2003a).

Redox equilibria are affected by the gas atmosphere, the temperature and furthermore by the basic composition of the melt. For example, if in an alkali silicate melt, the alkali concentration is increased, the Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ -equilibrium is shifted to the oxidized state (see e.g. Gerlach et al., 1998cGerlach et al., , 1999)). The effect of glass composition on the redox equilibrium has been described using empirical formulae taking into account the individual contribution of each melt component. Here, in most studies, a linear effect upon the equilibrium was assumed. This is questionable, at least if a melt component, such as alumina (or boron) may change its incorporation (see e.g. Toplis et al., 1997;Wiedenroth and Ru ¨ssel, 2002a) with the concentration, especially with the ratio network modifier Al 2 O 3 . Then the effect of the respective species cannot be described using a constant increment.
This paper provides a study of the Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ equilibrium and the iron diffusivity in melts in the system Na 2 O/MgO/CaO/Al 2 O 3 /SiO 2 using squarewave voltammetry.

div.head: Experimental procedure
div.p: Glasses in the system Na 2 O/MgO/CaO/Al 2 O 3 /SiO 2 doped with 0.25 mol% Fe 2 O 3 were melted from reagent grades Na 2 CO 3 , MgCO 3 , CaCO 3 , Al(OH) 3 and SiO 2 . Al(OH) 3 was used because of its larger dissolution rate in the melts. Batches of 200 g were melted in a platinum crucible using a high temperature furnace with MoSi 2 heating elements. The melts were kept at 1600 8C for 1 h and subsequently were cast on a graphite form preheated to 600 8C.

The experimental equipment and the procedure used have already been described in detail by Claugen and Ru ¨ssel (1996). A resistance heated furnace (MoSi 2 ) with dc power supply was used. In its middle, a platinum crucible containing the melt was located. From the top, three electrodes were inserted into the melt: a platinum wire (1 mm diameter) as the working electrode, a platinum plate as counter electrode (size: 2 cm 2 ) and a ZrO 2 -based reference flushed with air as reference electrode. The electronic equipment was self-constructed. The potentiostat, the main part of the electronic equipment, controlled the potentials in such a manner that the potential between working and reference electrode is always equal to the required value. The potentiostat was connected to a computer by analogue/digitaland digital/analogue-converters. The computer gave the potential-time dependence and recorded the current. The potential-time dependence was a staircase ramp superimposed by a rectangular wave (step time s=10-400 ms, potential amplitude DE=100 mV). The current was measured at the end of every half-wave and then differentiated. The fundamentals of this method have already been described by Barker (1958), Osteryoung and O'Dea (1986) and Osteryoung and Osteryoung (1985). The obtained current-potential curves were deconvoluted by experimentally recorded matrix currents and theoretically calculated current-potential curves, as described by Claugen and Ru ¨ssel (1996). The curves exhibit distinct maxima which peak potentials are equal to the standard potentials, E 0 , of the Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ -redox pair, and correlated with the equi-librium constant KV(T), the standard enthalpy, DH 0 , and the standard entropy, DS 0 , of the redox reaction according to Eq. (1).
div.formula: DG 0 T ð Þ ¼ DH 0 À T DS 0 ¼ À nFE 0 T ð Þ ¼ À RT lnKV T ð Þð4Þ
div.p: with n=number of electrons transferred (=1 for Fe 2+ / Fe 3+ ), DG 0 (T)=standard free enthalpy, R, T and F have their usual meaning.
From the peak currents, I p , the diffusion coefficients can be calculated:
div.formula: I p ¼ constAD 1=2 C 0 s À1=2ð5Þ
div.p: with A=area of the working electrode, C 0 =total concentration of the polyvalent ion, D=mean diffusion coefficient of Fe 2+ and Fe 3+ , const=0.31p À1/2 F 2 DEn 2 /(RT). Previous to the measurement, the melt was kept for 15 min at the respective temperature to allow thermal equilibration. An equilibration with the surrounding atmosphere is not necessary to carry out the measurement.

div.p: At 1600 8C, the peak potential is À145 mV. With decreasing temperature, the peak potential gets more negative. The peak currents strongly decrease with temperature. This is caused by decreasing diffusion coefficients.

In Fig. 2, peak potentials measured in melts with the basic compositions 10Na 2 Od xMgOd 10Al 2 O 3 d (80Àx)SiO 2 are shown as a function of the temperature. In a certain temperature range, a linear correlation between the peak potential and the temperature is observed within the limits of error. This enables the calculation of the standard enthalpy and the standard entropy according to Eq. ( 4). These values as well as the peak potentials of all compositions studied are summarized in Table 1. Below a temperature of 1300 and 1350 8C, deviations from linearity are observed in the melts with 15 and 20 mol% MgO, respectively. This is due to crystallization of forsterite (Mg 2 SiO 4 ) as proved by X-ray diffraction.

In Fig. 3, diffusion coefficients as calculated by Eq. ( 5) are shown for melts with the basic compositions 10Na 2 Od xMgOd (15Àx)CaOd 15Al 2 O 3 d 60SiO 2 as a function of the reciprocal temperature. The measurements were performed using different step times, s, usually 2, 5, 10, 20, 50, 100, 200 and 400 ms. Larger step times resulted in smaller peak currents, I p . For step times N10 ms, a proportionality between I p and s À1/2 as supposed for a diffusion controlled electrode reaction is obtained within the limits of error. Some melt compositions doped with 0.5 mol% Fe 2 O 3 were additionally studied. Here, within the limits of error, the peak currents were twice as large as in melts doped with 1 mol% Fe 2 O 3 . These experimental observations prove that the electrode reaction is diffusion controlled and the diffusion coefficients can be calculated from the respective peak potentials. Here, within the limits of error (F10%) linearity is observed, i.e. the diffusion coefficients obtained can be fitted to Arrhenius equation (see Eq. ( 7)). 4). This has also been reported by Ru ¨ssel (1993) for melts with the basic composition xK 2 Od 10CaOd (90Àx)SiO 2 . The diffusion coefficients increase with increasing soda concentrations. If referenced to the same viscosity (i.e. not temperature), the diffusion coefficients decrease with increasing Na 2 O concentration, i.e. iron gets less mobile and its incorporation becomes stronger. This is illustrated in Fig. 5 for the compositions xNa 2 Od 10MgOd (90Àx)SiO 2 . As known from Mfssbauer spectroscopy (see e.g. Nishida, 1994), Fe 3+ is incorporated predominantly in fourfold coordination. The FeO 4 À tetrahedra have formally a negative charge which needs to be compensated by an alkali ion. Increasing alkali concentrations hence lead to a better stabilization of the FeO 4 À tetrahedra. This results in more negative standard potentials. The smaller viscosity corrected diffusion coefficients are caused by the more covalent bonds of the tetrahedral FeO 4 À structure.

div.head: Effect of Al 2 O 3 concentration in Na 2 O/CaO/SiO 2 melts
div.p: Small alumina concentrations incorporated in alkali-lime-silicate melts lead to less negative standard potentials as shown in À tetrahedra (see e.g. Taylor andBrown, 1979 or Navrotsky et al., 1982), which in analogy to FeO 4 À tetrahedra also need cations for charge compensation. Therefore, increasing Al 2 O 3 concentrations lead to decreasing alkali concentrations available to compensate the charge of FeO 4 À tetrahedra. Therefore, the substitution of SiO 2 by Al 2 O 3 results in less negative standard potentials. At constant temperature, increasing Al 2 O 3 concentrations lead to increasing diffusion coefficients. If referenced to the same viscosity also increasing diffusion coefficients are observed. This can also be explained by the smaller Na 2 O concentrations available to compensate the charge of the FeO 4
À tetrahedra. This leads to a less strong incorporation and hence to increasing viscosity corrected diffusion coefficients.

If larger Al 2 O 3 concentrations are incorporated into the melt, the standard potentials decrease again after reaching a maximum at a certain Al 2 O 3 concentration. As shown in Fig. 6 If the stabilization of AlO 4 À and FeO 4 À tetrahedra would only be achieved by Na + , the maximum should occur if [Na 2 O] and [Al 2 O 3 ] are the same, because at further increasing Al 2 O 3 concentration, additional alumina is no longer charge balanced and should be incorporated as network modifier as reported by Mysen et al. (1985), or as triclusters as proposed (e.g. by Lacy, 1963;Engelhardt et al., 1985 andToplis et al., 1997). Since the maximum occurs at a larger À or FeO 4 À tetrahedron and hence, for charge balancing should also be coordinated with a nonbridging oxygen.

Viscosity corrected iron diffusion coefficients increase if small concentrations of alumina are incorporated. After a maximum at [Al 2 O 3 ]= [Na 2 O]+[CaO]/2 is reached, a slight decrease in the viscosity corrected diffusion coefficients is observed (see Fig. 7). This behaviour can be explained by the structural model described above. First, increasing alumina concentrations leads to less Na 2 O and CaO available to stabilize the FeO 4 À tetrahedra and hence to larger iron mobilities and larger diffusion coefficients. After the alumina concentration exceeds [Na 2 O]+[CaO]/2, additional alumina is not charge balanced; then the viscosity corrected iron diffusion coefficients decrease again.

In ternary Na 2 O/Al 2 O 3 /SiO 2 melts, the viscosity exhibits a maximum which appears at [Na 2 O]/[Al 2 O 3 ] ratios in the range of 0.82 to 1.0 as reported by Toplis et al. (1997). In the peraluminous range, the viscosity drops again. The exact composition at which the maximum in viscosity appears depends on the SiO 2 concentration. This behaviour has been explained in a similar manner to the structural model described above. In ternary CaO/Al 2 O 3 /SiO 2 melts, the viscosity also exhibits a maximum. As pointed out by Toplis and Dingwell (in press), the maximum is observed at a [CaO]/[Al 2 O 3 ] ratio of 0.81 to 0.92, i.e. at CaO concentrations smaller than that of tectosilicates at which composition according to Mysen (1988) the melt is fully polymerized. The shift to molar concentration ratios b1 was explained by the simultaneous occurrence of non-bridging oxygen, charge balanced AlO 4

À tetrahedra, and non-charge balanced alumina. In Fig. 2, the effect of the MgO concentration on the standard potentials in melts with the compositions 10Na 2 Od xMgOd 10Al 2 O 3 d (80Àx)SiO 2 is shown for different temperatures. At 1600 8C, the standard potentials are À120 and À240 mV for 5 and 20 mol% MgO, respectively. The standard potentials decrease linearly (within the limits of error) with increasing MgO concentration. Viscosity corrected iron diffusion coefficients decrease steadily with increasing MgO concentration as shown in Fig. 9. Since as described above, Mg 2+ does not contribute to the stabilization of AlO 4 À and FeO 4 À tetrahedra, the effect of MgO is different from that of CaO and cannot be explained by the structural model described above. The effect of Mg 2+ is more likely caused by the similarities to Fe 2+ . The ionic radii of Mg 2+ and Fe 2+ are 0.78 and 0.83 2, respectively (see e.g. Scholze, 1988). Also the metal-oxygen bond lengths in sixfold coordination (2.1 and 2.15 2, respectively, see Scholze, 1988) are fairly similar. Therefore, Mg 2+ and Fe 2+ should occupy similar sites in the glass structure. Increasing MgO concentrations then lead to the incorporation of Fe 2+ in energetically less advantageous sites. Hence, the decreasing standard potentials are not caused by the stabilization of Fe 3+ , i.e. FeO 4 À tetrahedra, but by the destabilization of Fe 2+ with increasing MgO concentration. div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Voltammetry in melts in the system Na 2 O/MgO/ CaO/Al 2 O 3 /SiO 2 enables the determination of standard potentials of the Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ equilibrium. From the standard potentials, equilibrium constants and, if the oxygen activity of the melt is known, Fe 2+ /Fe 3+ redox ratios can be calculated. From the respective peak currents of the voltammograms, iron diffusion coefficients can be calculated. Increasing the alkali concentration results in a shift of the redox equilibrium to the oxidized state and in smaller viscosity corrected iron diffusion coefficients. An increase in the alumina concentration up to [Al 2 O 3 ]=[Na 2 O]+ [CaO]/2 results in a shift of the redox equilibrium to the reduced state and in larger viscosity corrected iron diffusion coefficients. A further increase in the alumina concentration has the opposite effect.

This can be explained by a structural model assuming in the peralkaline range the occurrence of FeO 4 À and AlO 4 À which both are charge balanced by Na + . Larger alkali concentrations then lead to a better stabilization of FeO 4 À , while larger Al 2 O 3 concentrations result in a smaller stabilization. In the peraluminous range, alumina also occurs which is not charge balanced, i.e. incorporated as octahedra or triclusters. This leads to increasing stabilization of FeO 4

À tetrahedra. Magnesia does not contribute to the charge balance of AlO 4 À tetrahedra; however, increasing MgO concentrations shift the redox equilibrium to the oxidized form. This is supposedly due to the similarities of Mg 2+ and Fe 2+ with respect to their ionic radii and metal-oxygen bond lengths. Increasing MgO concentrations should lead to the incorporation of Fe 2+ in energetically less advantageous sites. 10) as a function of experimentally determined peak potentials of all melts studied (at 1300 8C).
